report_title: Industry Report: Pool and Billiard Halls
executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2021 currency.

The Pool and Billiard Halls industry is composed of operators that provide a space for consumers to play pool and other cue sports. Pool and billiard halls typically charge customers by the hour to use tables, with fees that generally range between $6.00 and $12.00. However, some pool halls may also maintain coin-operated pool tables, in which minimal staff supervision is needed. Additionally, pool halls operate arcade games, prize machines and gear and merchandise sales, which provide another source of revenue for industry operators. Lastly, pool and billiard halls often sell food and beverages to customers, with operations that range from packaged snacks and vending machines to a full-service bar and restaurant.

Over most of the five years to 2021, most macroeconomic factors affecting the industry demonstrated positive growth. Per capita disposable income grew and consumer confidence in the economy sharply increased, causing consumers to liberally spend on discretionary activities, such as sports and entertainment. Nevertheless, the industry has experienced steady declines, with revenue suffering primarily due to increased external competition from video games, mobile devices and related industries, such as bowling centers, family fun centers and others. Moreover, in 2020, industry revenue and profit are expected to suffer from the mandatory closure of nonessential businesses.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As a result of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, industry revenue is expected to decline at an annualized rate of 9.2% to $637.9 million over the five years to 2021, including 7.7% growth in 2021 alone.

Pool and billiard halls often sell merchandise, which provide another source of revenue for industry operators. Lastly, pool and billiard halls often sell food and beverages to customers, with operations that range from packaged snacks and vending machines to a full-service bar and restaurant.

Operators in this industry provide discretionary entertainment and a place to congregate for consumers. Indeed, pool and billiard halls that offer full-service bars operate similarly as businesses in the Bars and Nightclubs industry (IBISWorld report 72241). Overall, similar to other industries in the amusement and recreation sector, demand for pool and billiard halls is highly driven by disposable income levels and general consumer sentiment.

During most of the period, many macroeconomic factors affecting the industry demonstrated positive growth. Per capita disposable income grew and consumer spending increased, causing consumers to liberally spend on discretionary activities, such as sports and entertainment. However, these positive developments did not benefit industry operators.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, industry revenue is forecast to recover modestly, due to improvements in macroeconomic conditions. The US economy is projected to improve over the next five years, with unemployment rates remaining low. Moreover, per capita disposable income is anticipated to continue rising, which will likely bolster discretionary spending on leisure and recreational activities, such as industry services.

Over the five years to 2026, per capita disposable income is forecast to rise. As disposable income rises and unemployment remains low, consumers typically have an increasingly positive outlook regarding the economy. Consequently, the Consumer Confidence Index is projected to increase at an annualized rate.

Over the next five years, industry operators are expected to expand their array of ancillary services during the outlook period to capture the attention of a wider customer base. Moreover, food and beverages, particularly alcoholic beverages, typically command higher profit than pool tables.

Pool halls compete with bars for business. Similarly, pool halls that have a successful merchandise business, such as offering cues, balls and accessories, can generate revenue from casual pool players that occasionally visit pool halls. Nevertheless, industry profit will likely experience upward pressures despite internal and external competition.

Although both profit and revenue are expected to bounce back, operators are projected to continue exiting the industry, albeit at a slower rate. The number of enterprises is forecast to decline at an annualized rate of 3.9% to 714 operators over the five years to 2026. Following suit, industry employment is anticipated to fall at an annualized rate of 0.1% to 7,934 workers during the same period.

industry_definition: This industry operates facilities where consumers can play cue sports, such as eight-ball and nine-ball. Also known as billiard halls, these facilities may also offer gaming machines, foosball, darts and other games.

threats: Low Performance Drivers - Per capita disposable income

Pool halls have competed by upgrading tables, lowering prices and expanding their merchandise offerings
As industry revenue plummeted and profit wavered, many operators have exited the industry
Pool and billiard halls will likely continue to have difficulty attracting younger customers
Industry revenue is anticipated to recover to the levels experienced prior to the pandemic

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Spending on pool and billiards is discretionary. Consequently, demand for industry offerings is dependent on disposable incomes. When incomes climb, consumers have more money to go out to industry establishments. However, when incomes fall, consumers have less money to spend on billiards.
Industry revenue has declined as consumers have spent less on billiards and turn to alternative forms of entertainment. In particular, more consumers have turned to video games during leisure time.
When consumers do go out, they are increasingly preferring to go to bars for drinks or all-in-one venues. These venues offer billiards in addition to other activities and table games.

Owners seeking to differentiate the services offered from typical bars and pubs for casual and competitive pool players may increase the amount of merchandise and repair services offered moving forward.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Most states require pool/billiard halls with over a certain number of tables to obtain an operating license.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Licensing for alcoholic beverages, health, safety
regulations_points.regulation_description: Pool halls are subject to licensing by authorities for alcoholic beverages, health, safety and fire codes.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Initial capital investment required for equipment and facilities
barriers_points.barrier_description: The most substantial barrier to entry is the initial capital investment required to open an establishment, including facility rentals/leases, pool tables, balls, cue sticks, racks and other equipment.
Difficulty generating sufficient capital to cover initial purchases remains the largest barrier to entry for potential operators.

basis_points.basis_title: Texas, New York, Florida and Pennsylvania account for large share of US population and industry locations
basis_points.basis_description: Texas, New York, Florida and Pennsylvania account for a combined 25.2% of the US population and operate 6.7%, 5.9%, 5.8% and 4.2% of industry locations, respectively, in 2021.

basis_points.basis_title: State shares of establishments remained relatively stable
basis_points.basis_description: IBISWorld anticipates that each state's share of establishments has remained relatively stable over the five years to 2021, although the number of industry locations will likely decline across most regions over the coming years.

basis_points.basis_title: Pool halls in rural areas declining due to prevalence of basic equipment in bars
basis_points.basis_description: Pool and billiard halls in rural areas will likely decline due to the increasing prevalence of basic pool tables and billiard equipment in most other bars.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Highly fragmented industry with many small independent operators
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is highly fragmented and consists of a large number of small, independent businesses that are often family-owned and operated.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 4 players account for less than 5% of revenue
concentration_points.concentration_description: In 2021, IBISWorld estimates that the top four industry players will account for far less than 5.0% of industry revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Average operator employs less than 10 people per location
concentration_points.concentration_description: An average industry operator employs less than 10 people per location and generally only operates one location.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many employees work part-time for basic functions like bartending, maintenance and cleanup.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase costs for equipment and supplies
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs include pool tables, cues, balls, food, beverages and other products.
Many pool halls do not own facilities, resulting in high rental costs for good locations.
Utility costs, mainly electricity, account for 2.7% of industry revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Initial capital investment can be high
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The initial capital investment required to open a pool hall can be quite high, contributing to the industry's moderate level of capital intensity.
Start-up costs include facility rentals/leases, pool tables, balls, cue sticks, racks and other equipment.
Larger pool halls with food/beverage services must purchase industrial kitchen equipment and machinery, increasing capital costs.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Dependent on disposable income and leisure time
volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry revenue is largely based on disposable income levels and available leisure time.
External competition from other entertainment forms like family fun centers impacts revenue volatility.
Revenue declined 24.8% in 2020 due to temporary shutdowns from the COVID-19 pandemic.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Some operators have added credit card payment options to replace coin-operated tables.
Operators have purchased security systems to promote safety and protect from liabilities.

FAQs.question: How well does your company market to consumers with limited leisure time?
FAQs.answer: Operators compete for consumers' leisure time with a plethora of parallel industries, such as bowling centers, family fun centers, casinos and bars.

FAQs.question: Are your company's prices competitive with both direct competitors and alternative forms of entertainment?
FAQs.answer: There is not much price-based competition among industry operators. However, industry services are generally perceived as being much more affordable than competing forms of entertainment.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators are generally located near and around areas of high population density, as operators located near other similar entertainment options generally fare better.

FAQs.question: Are your products and services well-rounded to mitigate sudden changes in demand?
FAQs.answer: Traditional, operators focused on only offering pool and billiard services. However, recently, as demand for traditional industry services has plummeted, operators have increasingly offered ancillary services, such as food and drink and arcades.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored lowering wage costs through part-time labor and automation via point-of-sale systems?
FAQs.answer: Many operators keep wage costs low, as pool tables may be coin operated and do not require additional assistance. However, with the introduction of expanded restaurant services at many locations, operators have experienced a rise in wages as a share of revenue.

FAQs.question: Have you established a strong internet presence through social media platforms to capture a larger audience?
FAQs.answer: Operators have been slow to market themselves via the internet. However, larger operators, such as Q-Masters, have been able to increase their consumer base by marketing on various social media platforms.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with legislative and regulatory changes that may allow your company to expand into new markets?
FAQs.answer: The industry is not subject to many regulations that would affect operators' ability to expand their operations. However, establishments with food and drink services must stay up-to-date with alcoholic beverage regulations.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to federal or state regulation?
FAQs.answer: Many operators offer league services, which act as the industry's closest form of memberships agreements. However, these leagues are not subject to federal or state regulation.

FAQs.question: Is your company profit margin similar to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit varies, depending on an operator's size, location and services offered. For instance, operators with food and drink offerings generally report higher profit figures than their competitors.

FAQs.question: How can you maintain superior service while reducing operating costs?
FAQs.answer: Operators can reduce wage costs by switching to coin-operated pool tables, as these require minimal assistance. Moreover, operators with food and drink offerings can reduce wage costs by making these services largely self-serve.

FAQs.question: How loyal is your customer base? How do you ensure repeat customers? What percentage of revenue is devoted to retaining customers?
FAQs.answer: It is essential to ensure a high level of regular customers that spread good word-of-mouth recommendations to others.

FAQs.question: What are some ways that your company ensures that your facilities are kept in good condition for your customers?
FAQs.answer: Carrying out all necessary maintenance to keep facilities in good condition. Maintaining clean facilities and providing quality billiard equipment is necessary to increase the number of repeat customers.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Operators must be located near residential areas to encourage consumers to spend money on entertainment outside of the home.

FAQs.question: Do you track to number of adults aged 20 to 64? What age range are your customers typically?
FAQs.answer: Adults aged 20 to 64 comprise the primary market for pool and billiard halls. As a result, an expanding population within this age group creates a bigger potential market for pool and billiard halls. Industry operators that can successfully target the growing market can experience greater revenue growth.

FAQs.question: What risk management strategies are in place to soften the effect of low consumer sentiment?
FAQs.answer: Discretionary products and services, including pool and billiard halls, are dependent on consumer confidence, as consumers are more likely to partake in discretionary leisure when they are confident in the outlook for the economy. In 2020, the Consumer Confidence Index is expected to decline.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels?
FAQs.answer: Pool and other cue sports are considered by consumers to be discretionary leisure activities. Consumers are more likely to spend money on discretionary leisure activities when income is high.
